statement:
Let $\Sigma$ be a fixed signature, and ${\mathfrak{A}}$ and
${\mathfrak{B}}$ structures for $\Sigma$. If
$f \colon {\mathfrak{A}}\to {\mathfrak{B}}$ is a homomorphism, then
there is a unique bimorphism
$\phi\colon{\mathfrak{A}}/\!\ker(f) \to \operatorname{im}(f)$ such that
for all $a \in {\mathfrak{A}}$, $\phi({[\![a]\!]}) = f(a)$. Furthermore,
if $f$ has the additional property that for each $n \in {\mathbb{N}}$
and each $n$-ary relation symbol $R$ of $\Sigma$,
$$R^{\mathfrak{B}}(f(a_1), \ldots, f(a_n)) \Implies \exists a_i'[ f(a_i) = f(a_i') \land R^{\mathfrak{A}}(a_1', \ldots, a_n')],$$
then $\phi$ is an isomorphism.

Since the homomorphic image of a $\Sigma$-structure is also a
$\Sigma$-structure, we may assume that
$\operatorname{im}(f) = {\mathfrak{B}}$.

Let $\sim\ = \ker(f)$. Define a bimorphism
$\phi \colon {\mathfrak{A}}{/\!\!\sim}\to {\mathfrak{B}}: {[\![a]\!]} \mapsto f(a)$.
To verify that $\phi$ is well defined, let $a \sim a'$. Then
$\phi({[\![a]\!]}) = f(a) = f(a') = \phi({[\![a']\!]})$. To show that
$\phi$ is injective, suppose $\phi({[\![a]\!]}) = \phi({[\![a']\!]})$.
Then $f(a) = f(a')$, so $a \sim a'$. Hence ${[\![a]\!]} = {[\![a']\!]}$.
To show that $\phi$ is a homomorphism, observe that for any constant
symbol $c$ of $\Sigma$ we have
$\phi({[\![c^{\mathfrak{A}}]\!]}) = f(c^{\mathfrak{A}}) = c^{\mathfrak{B}}$.
For each $n \in {\mathbb{N}}$ and each $n$-ary function symbol $F$ of
$\Sigma$, $$\begin{aligned}
\phi(F^{{\mathfrak{A}}/\!\sim}({[\![a_1]\!]}, \ldots, {[\![a_n]\!]})) &= \phi({[\![F^{\mathfrak{A}}(a_1, \ldots, a_n)]\!]}) \\
&= f(F^{\mathfrak{A}}(a_1, \ldots, a_n)) \\
&= F^{\mathfrak{B}}(f(a_1), \ldots, f(a_n)) \\
&= F^{\mathfrak{B}}(\phi({[\![a_1]\!]}, \ldots, \phi({[\![a_n]\!]})).\end{aligned}$$
For each $n \in {\mathbb{N}}$ and each $n$-ary relation symbol $R$ of
$\Sigma$, $$\begin{aligned}
R^{{\mathfrak{A}}/\!\sim}({[\![a_1]\!]}, \ldots, {[\![a_n]\!]}) &\Implies R^{\mathfrak{A}}(a_1, \ldots, a_n) \\
&\Implies R^{\mathfrak{B}}(f(a_1), \ldots, f(a_n)) \\
&\Implies R^{\mathfrak{B}}(\phi({[\![a_1]\!]}, \ldots, \phi({[\![a_n]\!]})).\end{aligned}$$
Thus $\phi$ is a bimorphism.

Now suppose $f$ has the additional property mentioned in the statement
of the theorem. Then $$\begin{aligned}
R^{\mathfrak{B}}(\phi({[\![a_1]\!]}), \ldots, \phi({[\![a_n]\!]})) 
&\Implies R^{\mathfrak{B}}(f(a_1), \ldots, f(a_n)) \\
&\Implies  \exists a_i'[ a_i \sim a_i' \land R^{\mathfrak{A}}(a_1', \ldots, a_n')] \\
&\Implies R^{{\mathfrak{A}}/\!\sim}({[\![a_1]\!]}, \ldots, {[\![a_n]\!]}) .\end{aligned}$$
Thus $\phi$ is an isomorphism.
